Follow today’s news liveGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastMatt Canavan says landmark climate assessment a ‘cynical attempt to spread fear and panic’Nationals senator Matt Canavan discounted the headlines behind the landmark national climate risk assessment, saying the government had conveniently timed the report while calling the document a “cynical attempt to spread fear and panic among people”.The problem is the headline figures are never as bad as the detailed science that underlies it. …It reads like the Book of Daniel, not a government report. I mean, I like government reports that are sober and reasonable. … I think Australians like a government, that just tell them the truth and not try and scare them. We saw that during Covid. People are trying to scare you because they’ve got an agenda, right? Continue reading...

items.title: One dead, several injured from gas leak at Sydney restaurant
items.standfirst: Five police are among those rushed to hospital.
items.content: O ne person is dead and six others are injured, including five police officers, after a gas leak in north-west Sydney.Emergency services responded to reports of a gas leak at a restaurant on Garfield Road in Riverstone this morning.One person was confirmed dead at the scene. Five police officers and a member of the public were taken to Blacktown Hospital in a stable condition.READ MORE: Brisbane man allegedly stabbed in his sleep, doused in petrolWhen emergency services arrived, they found people in the building overcome by the gas."A number of people have been exposed to some kind of gas," Superintendent Adam Newberry said."I understand a number of people appear to have been affected by carbon monoxide poisoning."This is a developing situation or emergency." READ MORE: SA Police probe employee's posts allegedly celebrating Charlie Kirk assassinationWarren Kirby, the state member for Riverstone, expressed his condolences to those impacted."I am deeply saddened to learn of the tragic death and hospitalisations in Riverstone following the gas leak at a local restaurant," he told 9news.com.au in a statement."My thoughts are with the family of the person who has died and with everyone affected, including first responders and their loved ones."Investigations are underway to establish the source of the gas leak. I have also asked for immediate updates from NSW Health on the status of those hospitalised." This is a breaking story. More to come...

items.title: Community fights lead mine near primary school as report highlights Australia’s failure to protect children
items.standfirst: Report commissioned by Mudgee health alliance suggests mine’s health and environmental assessments accepted by NSW government contain errors and outdated evidenceFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastAn application for a lead mine 2km from a primary school has failed to address concerns about its predicted emissions, relies on outdated evidence and has a community group in New South Wales rightly concerned for their health, a new expert report says.The author of the report also noted Australia’s record of failing to protect children in the vicinity of lead mines. The environment watchdog sat on a report linking contemporary lead mining to health affects on children but failed to release it during the mine’s original application and a subsequent parliamentary inquiry into the mine. Continue reading...

items.title: Sea level rise and soaring heat deaths: will climate action match the risks? - podcast
items.standfirst: The national climate risk assessment has painted a challenging and confronting view of the future for Australia under global heating. Anthony Albanese says the landmark report is a ‘wake-up call’ that reinforces the need for ‘serious’ action on the climate emergency. But with the government’s soon-to-be released 2035 emissions target still unknown, will Labor’s action on the climate crisis match the risk?Nour Haydar speaks with climate and environment editor Adam Morton about how the government will respond to its biggest climate challengeYou can subscribe for free to Guardian Australia’s daily news podcast Full Story on Apple Podcasts and Spotify. Continue reading...

Anthony Albanese says the landmark report is a ‘wake-up call’ that reinforces the need for ‘serious’ action on the climate emergency. But with the government’s soon-to-be released 2035 emissions target still unknown, will Labor’s action on the climate crisis match the risk?Nour Haydar speaks with climate and environment editor Adam Morton about how the government will respond to its biggest climate challengeYou can subscribe for free to Guardian Australia’s daily news podcast Full Story on Apple Podcasts and Spotify. items.title: The government has laid out the perils of the climate crisis – but will Albanese meet the moment?
items.standfirst: Grave remarks on the potential shocks to people, property and the economy are all too familiar. Putting a credible number on the emissions target is the harder partSign up for climate and environment editor Adam Morton’s free Clear Air newsletter hereFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastIt is hard to imagine there will be a more important piece of work put out by the Albanese government in this term of parliament than the national climate risk assessment. It suggests that at more than 2C of global heating – a level we are headed towards on our current trajectory – the systems Australians rely on could start to crumble and collapse.That’s an easy thing to say, but a hard thing to get your head around. There was a huge amount of information released on Monday, including an adaptation plan that is only the start of grappling with the problem, and it will take time to digest. But it is worth considering what the assessment led by the Australian Climate Service says about the country’s economic future if global emissions are not curbed and temperatures continue to rise.Sign up to get climate and environment editor Adam Morton’s Clear Air column as a free newsletter Continue reading...
items.content: Grave remarks on the potential shocks to people, property and the economy are all too familiar. Putting a credible number on the emissions target is the harder partSign up for climate and environment editor Adam Morton’s free Clear Air newsletter hereFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastIt is hard to imagine there will be a more important piece of work put out by the Albanese government in this term of parliament than the national climate risk assessment. It suggests that at more than 2C of global heating – a level we are headed towards on our current trajectory – the systems Australians rely on could start to crumble and collapse.That’s an easy thing to say, but a hard thing to get your head around. There was a huge amount of information released on Monday, including an adaptation plan that is only the start of grappling with the problem, and it will take time to digest. But it is worth considering what the assessment led by the Australian Climate Service says about the country’s economic future if global emissions are not curbed and temperatures continue to rise.Sign up to get climate and environment editor Adam Morton’s Clear Air column as a free newsletter Continue reading...

items.content: A man has been charged after allegedly stabbing a man known to him while he was sleeping in his West End home on Saturday.

items.title: Brisbane man allegedly stabbed in his sleep, doused in petrol
items.standfirst: A man has been stabbed in his sleep by another man known to him, who allegedly broke into his Brisbane home on Saturday morning.
items.content: A man has been stabbed in his sleep by another man known to him, who allegedly broke into his Brisbane home on Saturday morning.Police say a 25-year-old man from Camira broke into a home on Mollison Street in West End and stabbed a sleeping 27-year-old man in the torso at 5.15am.He then allegedly began pouring petrol on his victim before being interrupted by another person in the home.READ MORE: Family seeks answers after Gold Coast mum Kelly Wilkinson stabbed, burnt to deathThe man fled the scene.Police and paramedics arrived and the victim was taken to hospital in a serious but stable condition.The man was arrested near a Morayfield shopping centre at 9.30am yesterday.He was charged with attempted murder and enter dwelling with intent. He will face Brisbane Magistrates Court this morning.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: SA Police probe employee's posts allegedly celebrating Charlie Kirk assassination

items.title: SA Police probe employee's posts allegedly celebrating Charlie Kirk assassination
items.standfirst: It has been reported the employee allegedly described Kirk's assassination at Utah Valley University last week as "wonderful".
items.content: S outh Australia Police said it is investigating a staff member's social media posts after they allegedly made comments celebrating the assassination of right-wing podcaster and activist Charlie Kirk.A spokesperson for SA Police confirmed it has been notified of the social media posts. "SAPOL are aware of the social media posts, and they are now subject to an investigation under the Police Complaints Disciplinary Act," the spokesperson said.READ MORE: Aussie staples under threat of being wiped out in just decades9News understands the employee allegedly described Kirk's assassination at Utah Valley University last week as "wonderful".Kirk, 31, was fatally shot at a campus event at Utah Valley University on September 11.T yler Robinson, 22, has been arrested in relation to Kirk's assassination.He is expected to be formally charged with murder.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: SA Police investigating social media post allegedly made by employee celebrating death of Charlie Kirk
items.standfirst: SA Police says it is investigating an employee's social media posts, after they allegedly made a post celebrating the assassination of the US right-wing political activist Charlie Kirk.
items.content: SA Police says it is investigating an employee's social media posts, after they allegedly made a post celebrating the assassination of the US right-wing political activist Charlie Kirk.

items.title: What do we know about Charlie Kirk's alleged killer?
items.standfirst: Investigations are continuing after the murder of American political commentator Charlie Kirk last week.
items.content: Investigations are continuing after the murder of American political commentator Charlie Kirk last week and the arrest of a suspect.The 31-year-old was shot in the neck and killed on a college campus in Utah on Thursday, sparking tributes from many politicians and figures, including Kirk's friend, President Donald Trump.It has also caused debate about the spate of violent attacks on American politicians in recent times.READ MORE: 'Note' left by Charlie Kirk shooting suspect under investigationA suspect has been arrested, with 22-year-old Tyler Robinson in custody and being interviewed by authorities.Here is what we know about Charlie Kirk's alleged shooter.What happened to Charlie Kirk?Kirk was on a speaking tour at Utah Valley College in Utah last Thursday when a gunshot was heard.Kirk, who was sitting underneath a tent and speaking to a gathered crowd, was shot in the neck by a single bullet at around 12.23pm local time.He was rushed to hospital and had emergency surgery, but he could not be saved.The shooter was seen climbing the roof of a nearby building before the shooting, and climbing down and retreating into the woods in the immediate aftermath.His death was announced by Trump, who called Kirk a "martyr for truth and freedom".READ MORE: Accused Kirk shooter's relationship with trans partner examinedWho shot Charlie Kirk?Two people were quickly arrested after the shooting, though it later emerged one of the arrests was an "obstruction of justice" charge and not connected to the shooting.Hours after the shooting, FBI director Kish Patel announced a suspect was in custody, which was corroborated by Utah Governor Spencer Cox; however, just two hours later, the suspect had been released.Over the weekend, inquiries narrowed to one suspect, and Robinson was arrested on September 12 at his home.The 22-year-old is from St George, Utah, and is in the third year of an electrical apprenticeship at Dixie Technical College.Robinson did not have a criminal record prior to his arrest.READ MORE: These siblings started a business with a few hundred bucks. It's made $20 millionHow was Tyler Robinson caught?Robinson was first identified as a suspect by his own father, who recognised his son from photos and videos released by law enforcement.Robinson's father reportedly confronted the 22-year-old and urged him to turn himself in, but Robinson refused.Despite this, Robinson reportedly confided in a youth pastor who was connected to law enforcement, and there were several clues connecting Robinson to the shooting.He was seen wearing a distinct outfit before and after the shooting, which was the same clothing he was later arrested in.Robinson also left messages on Discord, a social media service, saying he had to "pick up a rifle" and leave it in a bush.READ MORE: Teacher who beat cancer killed in tragic jet ski accidentWhat were Tyler Robinson's motives for allegedly shooting Charlie Kirk?Reports indicate Robinson had become more politically active in the lead-up to the shooting.He was deeply critical of Kirk and his views, with bullet casings of a rifle found by police allegedly inscribed with messages including "Hey fascist! Catch!" and other messages related to online game culture.Robinson had also made comments critical of Kirk at a recent family dinner, investigators were told.It is also believed Robinson may have been in a romantic relationship with his roommate, who is transitioning from male to female.Kirk was public in his views on transgender people, praising Trump for revoking an order allowing transgender people to openly serve in the military.Cox said the roommate had "no idea" about the shooting before it occurred. What are Tyler Robinson's beliefs?Tyler Robinson is a registered voter but isn't affiliated to any political party, and there is no evidence to suggest he had voted in his local county.According to reports, the rest of the Robinson family were Republican voters and his mother had expressed support for Trump.His family are members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, which is popular in Utah.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.
